repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh -  Fourth Population &
            Health and Health & Population Program Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This assessment concurred with the
            completion report ratings of the Fourth Population and
            Health Project (FPHP) in Bangladesh.  For the Health and
            Population Program Project (HPPP) it differed in the rating
            of modest institutional development impact and an
            unsatisfactory performance of the Bank.  The two projects
            have made a clear and demonstrable contribution to the
            Bangladesh's remarkable success in reducing fertility
            and under-five mortality.  Lessons learned include the
            following: aid-financed health infrastructure can work in
            improving health outcomes provided other conditions are in
            place; public and private provision are complements not
            substitutes; a sector wide approach (SWAP) takes time to
            implement and is an evolutionary process; wide stakeholder
            participation in preparation helps ownership but can weaken
            design; think through the implications of the new system;
            draw on the appropriate skills mix; failure to assess fully
            the political economy of reform and to prepare both a
            proactive plan for addressing/mitigating risks and a
            contingency plan will considerably diminish prospects for
            successful reform; too much donor/Bank intervention can
            undermine government capacity and ownership of a SWAP
            approach; and finally, be realistic in tackling major reform objectives.

repnme.cdata!: Bangladesh - Health and Population Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bangladesh Health and Population
            Program Project outcome is unsatisfactory; sustainability
            likely, institutional development impact substantial,
            overall Bank and Borrower performances satisfactory. The
            program offers insight into a number of important design and
            implementation issues with implications for other projects:
            Amongst the key lessons regarding SWAps, these lessons were
            cited: 1) SWAps can be gradually adopted, yielding
            increasing improvements in sector management even when the
            change is incomplete. 2) Mechanisms to facilitate
            implementation when the government has insufficient capacity
            or deficiencies yield good results and allow the government
            to gradually take on the responsibility. 3) Establish
            performance indicators and progress benchmarks for
            establishing the SWAps.    SWAps need to clearly define the
            scope of the "sector" to be managed so that key
            sector stakeholders are reached by program interventions and
            donors. Parallel funding should be discouraged. 5) Donor
            coordination requires negotiating skills, leadership, and
            presence in the field. A Code of Conduct with clear rules of
            engagement for coordinating and managing SWAps needs to be
            defined upfront, to ensure decisions are taken swiftly and
            program focus is maintained. Some lessons about managing
            institutional development included: 1) Not carrying out an
            analysis of the political economy of reforms can lead to
            failure. identify opposition whether within the health
            ministry, physician's associations, other worker's
            associations, or users of the services themselves. 2)
            Identify incentives for stakeholders to bolster
            institutional change. General lessons included: Take into
            account those too poor to consume government services;
            icharging them informal fees is too costly. Participatory
            preparation, while enhancing ownership, can dilute the focus
            of a project's design; strike a balance to ensure both
            goals are met.  Measure not just long-term outcomes but also
            intermediate indicators that would lead to those outcomes in
            order to ensure program effects can be measured. Set targets
            related to the capacity of the implementing entity. A risk
            management strategy must be an essential part of annual
            program reviews and routine project supervision.

repnme.cdata!: Bangladesh - Health and Population Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Health and
            Population Program Project are to achieve better access to
            essential services for the poor, lower maternal mortality
            and morbidity, and continued improvements in child health
            and family planning. Reorganization of and reform of public
            services are expected to enable the Government to improve
            the quality and utilization of its system and to allocate
            its limited resources more cost-effectively. The project
            components are: (a) service delivery and policy reform
            including an essential services package, hospital/other
            health and nutrition services, support services, and health
            policy reform, and (b) organization and management reform
            including reorganization and rationalization of the Ministry
            of Health and Family Welfare, Government of Bangladesh
            (MOHFW) and sector-wide program management.
